items.name: VS Code
items.desc: My daily editor. Clean, fast, and the extension ecosystem covers everything I need.

items.name: Cursor
items.desc: AI-native IDE on top of VS Code ‚Äî excellent for exploring unfamiliar codebases quickly.

items.name: Zsh + Oh My Zsh
items.desc: Shell with sensible defaults, aliases, and plugins (git, zsh-autosuggestions, syntax highlighting).

items.name: iTerm2
items.desc: Terminal emulator on macOS. Native splits, profiles per project, and solid colour themes.

items.name: tmux
items.desc: Session management for long-running processes ‚Äî invaluable when SSHing into remote servers.

items.name: Go
items.desc: My go-to (pun intended) for backend services. Compiled, fast, simple concurrency, and excellent tooling.

items.name: TypeScript
items.desc: For anything touching the web layer ‚Äî APIs, full-stack apps, tooling scripts.

items.name: Python
items.desc: Scripting, data processing, and quick prototypes. Hard to beat for one-off automation.

items.name: Node.js
items.desc: Runtime for TypeScript services and tooling when the JS ecosystem wins.

items.name: PostgreSQL
items.desc: First choice for relational data. Reliable, feature-rich, and the JSONB support is underrated.

items.name: MongoDB
items.desc: When the data model genuinely calls for documents. Used for content-heavy and flexible schemas.

items.name: Redis
items.desc: Caching, pub/sub, rate limiting, and session storage. Always nearby in the stack.

items.name: DynamoDB
items.desc: When I need single-digit millisecond latency at scale and can design around its constraints.

items.name: AWS
items.desc: Primary cloud. Mostly S3, Lambda, EC2, RDS, SNS/SQS, and IAM. Deep familiarity with the pricing model too.

items.name: Docker
items.desc: Containers for local dev parity, CI pipelines, and deployment. docker-compose for multi-service local setups.

items.name: GitHub Actions
items.desc: CI/CD pipelines. Simple YAML, good marketplace, free tier is generous.

items.name: Vercel
items.desc: Frontend and Next.js deployments. Zero-config, edge network, excellent DX.

items.name: Linux (Ubuntu)
items.desc: All production servers run Linux. Ubuntu for predictability, documentation density, and package availability.

items.name: Postman / Bruno
items.desc: API development and testing. Bruno for local-first, git-friendly collections.

items.name: DBeaver
items.desc: Database GUI that works with every database I use. Saves time on schema exploration.

items.name: Git
items.desc: Version control. Conventional commits, feature branches, squash merges. Nothing exotic.

items.name: k9s
items.desc: Terminal UI for Kubernetes. Makes cluster inspection and log tailing much less painful.

items.name: jq
items.desc: JSON on the command line. Indispensable when working with API responses in scripts.

items.name: Next.js 15 (App Router)
items.desc: Framework. Server components, static generation, and API routes all in one place.

items.name: Tailwind CSS
items.desc: Utility-first CSS. Once you internalize the scale, the speed is unmatched.

items.name: Supabase
items.desc: View counts, upvotes, and reports are stored here. Client-only; no API in the loop.

items.name: Vercel
items.desc: Deployment. Every push to main deploys in ~30 seconds.

items.name: Markdown + gray-matter
items.desc: All posts are plain Markdown files in the repo. No CMS, no database for content.

items.name: Obsidian
items.desc: Personal knowledge base and drafts. Local-first, Markdown, and the graph view is genuinely useful.

items.name: Linear
items.desc: Issue tracking for projects. Fast, keyboard-driven, and doesn't get in the way.

items.name: Excalidraw
items.desc: Whiteboard for system design diagrams. Hand-drawn look makes it feel low-stakes and fast to iterate.

items.name: Notion
items.desc: Team docs and wikis when collaborating. Not for personal notes (too slow), but good for shared knowledge.
